article:
A 'lateral canal' is a canal built along the same right-of-way as an existing
stream. Water for the canal is usually provided by the original natural stream.
Many French lateral canals have the word latÃ©ral as part of their name.
Examples include Canal latÃ©ral Ã  l'Aisne, Canal latÃ©ral Ã  la Garonne, and Canal
latÃ©ral Ã  la Marne.

The normal aim of constructing such a canal was to provide a more consistent
depth of water for navigation particularly during dry summers and to make
navigation easier during periods of flood. Problems often remained where the
original course of the river was still used.
